comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Wonderful photo of a nations and a family's loss.  I had never seen this before and it is very good.  Interesting to see how they hall was laid out to cope with those who wished to pay their respects to the fallen leader.

comment.author: 83634647@N00
comment._content: I was reading about Michael Collins and it said the last known photograph of him was in Bandon before the ambush.  Is this photograph in your collection?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/reneemartin] It's not in our online catalogue, Renee, I'll ask about uncatalogued photos and let you know...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 83634647@N00
comment._content:
oh wow, thanks!  I've just been reading coincidentally about Michael Collins recently and it is such an incredible history (incredible in the sense of cultural and historical relevance, not withstanding any political standpoints.)
love this flickr, you do such a great job!  I always check in every week

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/reneemartin] Lovely of you to say so, Renee, thanks!

comment._content: Thank you very much.  This is a photograph of my grandfather that I had never seen before.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment._content: Yes, he was indeed. You'll find a big chunk of the family tree at www.myheritage.com/site-169482341/hurley

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56469637@N02] Fascinating! And what a huge amount of work! The dedication and detective powers of family historians never ceases to amaze me...
